html: The rules were designed to facilitate public disclosure without threatening privacy or undermining a special counsel by requiring him to produce a public report. If that process fails, and the AG doesn’t provide appropriate transparency, Congress can *then* address it.
text: The rules were designed to facilitate public disclosure without threatening privacy or undermining a special counsel by requiring him to produce a public report. If that process fails, and the AG doesn’t provide appropriate transparency, Congress can *then* address it.

html: Mueller then has to write his report for a public audience, while knowing the public will hold him responsible for any fallout from the release. This could limit his ability to provide the AG all the appropriate information.
text: Mueller then has to write his report for a public audience, while knowing the public will hold him responsible for any fallout from the release. This could limit his ability to provide the AG all the appropriate information.

html: But if Congress insists now, before the report has been written, that the entire report be released, we effectively shift to Mueller the decisions about what to release publicly.
text: But if Congress insists now, before the report has been written, that the entire report be released, we effectively shift to Mueller the decisions about what to release publicly.

html: Mueller is required to write a report for the AG, who is then responsible for decisions about releasing information to the public. This is a valuable dynamic—it allows Mueller to put into his report exactly the information he thinks the AG should have.

html: Congress should (and I will) work to repeal laws that ostensibly grant legislative powers to the president. But even if Congress does no such thing, such laws are void under our Constitution, and any emergency declaration by the president for a non-emergency is likewise void.
text: Congress should (and I will) work to repeal laws that ostensibly grant legislative powers to the president. But even if Congress does no such thing, such laws are void under our Constitution, and any emergency declaration by the president for a non-emergency is likewise void.

html: It would mean that a simple majority of each chamber could delegate legislative powers to the president, but only a two-thirds majority or greater could reject their application to a particular case or repeal the delegation altogether.
text: It would mean that a simple majority of each chamber could delegate legislative powers to the president, but only a two-thirds majority or greater could reject their application to a particular case or repeal the delegation altogether.

html: Some have replied that Congress still retains legislative powers should the president abuse an emergency declaration. They note that Congress can pass legislation to override the president’s actions. Though true, this arrangement turns the Constitution on its head.
text: Some have replied that Congress still retains legislative powers should the president abuse an emergency declaration. They note that Congress can pass legislation to override the president’s actions. Though true, this arrangement turns the Constitution on its head.

html: Can Congress make a law permitting the president to conduct the entire appropriations process by his declaring an emergency? Of course not. That would impermissibly grant him legislative powers. The same principle applies when addressing a portion of the appropriations process.
text: Can Congress make a law permitting the president to conduct the entire appropriations process by his declaring an emergency? Of course not. That would impermissibly grant him legislative powers. The same principle applies when addressing a portion of the appropriations process.

html: Congress cannot turn the executive branch into the legislative branch. Such an effort fails for lack of conformity to our Constitution. The validity of an emergency declaration is limited by the definition of “emergency” itself and cannot be expanded by statutory openness.
text: Congress cannot turn the executive branch into the legislative branch. Such an effort fails for lack of conformity to our Constitution. The validity of an emergency declaration is limited by the definition of “emergency” itself and cannot be expanded by statutory openness.

html: Congress can make no law permitting the president to assume permanent legislative powers, even in a single area, simply by his declaring an emergency. The president may act quasi-legislatively only in an actual emergency—when Congress has no time to act—and then only temporarily.
text: Congress can make no law permitting the president to assume permanent legislative powers, even in a single area, simply by his declaring an emergency. The president may act quasi-legislatively only in an actual emergency—when Congress has no time to act—and then only temporarily.

html: Laws like the War Powers Resolution and the National Emergencies Act are not—and, under our Constitution, cannot be—grants of legislative powers to the president. They were adopted to transition authority back to Congress when unilateral executive action is no longer appropriate.
text: Laws like the War Powers Resolution and the National Emergencies Act are not—and, under our Constitution, cannot be—grants of legislative powers to the president. They were adopted to transition authority back to Congress when unilateral executive action is no longer appropriate.

html: Over the years, Congress has passed laws to create an orderly process for receding the president’s inherent emergency power as an emergency subsides—the War Powers Resolution and the National Emergencies Act are two examples.
text: Over the years, Congress has passed laws to create an orderly process for receding the president’s inherent emergency power as an emergency subsides—the War Powers Resolution and the National Emergencies Act are two examples.

html: Going back to the Framers of the Constitution, Americans have recognized the president’s inherent power as chief executive to act swiftly in an emergency, especially a sudden attack on the United States. But such power exists only so long as Congress has no opportunity to act.
text: Going back to the Framers of the Constitution, Americans have recognized the president’s inherent power as chief executive to act swiftly in an emergency, especially a sudden attack on the United States. But such power exists only so long as Congress has no opportunity to act.

html: A thread on national emergencies and our Constitution: Congress makes laws. The president executes laws. The Supreme Court decides cases. This is our constitutional system. Congress cannot delegate legislative powers to the president by statute.
text:
A thread on national emergencies and our Constitution:

Congress makes laws.
The president executes laws.
The Supreme Court decides cases.

This is our constitutional system.

Congress cannot delegate legislative powers to the president by statute.

text:
Ways to break shutdown stalemate:
1. @SpeakerPelosi and @senatemajldr open up process, allow amendment votes, and send compromise to president to sign or veto, or
2. @POTUS agrees to sign one-week CR every week while parties negotiate.

First is best but unlikely.
Second is easy.

text:
To make this more concrete:

Assume that furloughed federal workers will be paid for the period of any shutdown. Do you think they should go to work and be paid on time, or get sent home and be paid later?

Today’s bill sends them home and pays them later.

html: 3. @POTUS signs or vetoes. 4. If POTUS vetoes, House and Senate can vote to override veto. 5. If veto override fails, Congress and POTUS will need to rethink their positions, but they will have a much better sense of what’s achievable. This is our system. We should follow it.
text:
3. @POTUS signs or vetoes.

4. If POTUS vetoes, House and Senate can vote to override veto.

5. If veto override fails, Congress and POTUS will need to rethink their positions, but they will have a much better sense of what’s achievable.

This is our system. We should follow it.

html: This is more likely to be resolved well by following constitutional process: 1. House and Senate vote on amendments to fund the wall at various levels. 2A. If they agree on an amount, send spending bill to @POTUS. 2B. If they reject all amounts, send spending bill to POTUS.
text:
This is more likely to be resolved well by following constitutional process:

1. House and Senate vote on amendments to fund the wall at various levels.

2A. If they agree on an amount, send spending bill to @POTUS.

2B. If they reject all amounts, send spending bill to POTUS.

html: I don’t absolve the tax legislation from its debt impact, as I noted when I voted for it. I believe in lower taxes and lower spending—limited government—and that’s how I vote. That said, the annual spending bills (on which I vote no) have *far* more debt impact than the tax vote.

Being generous to @kasie (and others), let’s assume the tax law has an FY18 budget impact of a couple hundred billion dollars. That’s a lot of money—but far short of $2 trillion.

html: My Twitter feed is full of partisans on the right who think the left is destroying our country and partisans on the left who think the right is destroying our country. You don’t have to think the sides are equivalent to recognize the inherent biases that cloud people’s judgments.
text: My Twitter feed is full of partisans on the right who think the left is destroying our country and partisans on the left who think the right is destroying our country. You don’t have to think the sides are equivalent to recognize the inherent biases that cloud people’s judgments.

html: Whataboutism isn’t when you say the other side is wrong, too; it’s when you say the other side is wrong, too, and therefore my side is excused from wrongdoing. It’s fine to note that both sides are wrong as long as you acknowledge that it cannot excuse either side’s wrongdoing.
text:
Whataboutism isn’t when you say the other side is wrong, too; it’s when you say the other side is wrong, too, and therefore my side is excused from wrongdoing.

It’s fine to note that both sides are wrong as long as you acknowledge that it cannot excuse either side’s wrongdoing.

html: Each side also consistently employs whataboutism when you call them on some impropriety. We’ll start doing X when your side does X or Y, they love to say. My reply is that you need to take a risk and do the right thing regardless. We must rebuild trust to end this cycle.

I’m voting no on all four.

html: Worse yet, thanks to the press conference, we’re likely to see more ineffectual sanctions bills and resolutions of condemnation against Russia, which will serve primarily to stunt further efforts at diplomacy and dialogue.

html: The widespread reaction on Capitol Hill, for example, has been to rally around the intelligence community. People are proposing resolutions of support for the FBI, despite its dubious track record and unconstitutional activities, particularly with respect to the #4thAmendment.

html: Nor are libertarian values advanced when the effect of the president’s press conference—set aside the intent—is to further isolate our country from Russia.

html: People then connect our principles to the president’s failings, which have nothing to do with libertarianism.

html: The general public are not more likely to see themselves as libertarian when, for the sake of “owning the necons,” prominent figures associated with libertarianism conflate libertarian-style governance and Trump-style governance.

html: When a libertarian’s political prime directive becomes “owning the neocons” (or “owning the libs”) rather than advancing libertarian ideals, then that person undermines libertarianism as a philosophy.

html: The virtue being signaled is opposition to all things “neocon.” If someone doesn’t like how the meeting transpired, it must be because that person is a Deep State anti-Trump neocon warmonger, etc.
text: The virtue being signaled is opposition to all things “neocon.” If someone doesn’t like how the meeting transpired, it must be because that person is a Deep State anti-Trump neocon warmonger, etc.

html: To suggest that anyone critical of the president’s conduct opposes diplomacy is to employ a strawman argument. It’s virtue signaling, not libertarianism.
text: To suggest that anyone critical of the president’s conduct opposes diplomacy is to employ a strawman argument. It’s virtue signaling, not libertarianism.

html: Even the president ultimately recognized that the press conference did not go well, as he tried to correct his remarks that exonerated Russia. Oddly, it took him more than a day to do so. One wonders why the White House didn’t act more quickly if it were simply a misstatement.
text: Even the president ultimately recognized that the press conference did not go well, as he tried to correct his remarks that exonerated Russia. Oddly, it took him more than a day to do so. One wonders why the White House didn’t act more quickly if it were simply a misstatement.

html: Perhaps it was just the president showing insecurity, once again, over the legitimacy of his election. Perhaps it was a sign of a more troubling entanglement with Putin. Whatever the case, the press conference was counterproductive to the goal of improving relations.
text: Perhaps it was just the president showing insecurity, once again, over the legitimacy of his election. Perhaps it was a sign of a more troubling entanglement with Putin. Whatever the case, the press conference was counterproductive to the goal of improving relations.

html: The impression it left on me, a strong supporter of the meeting, is that “something is not right here.” The president went out of his way to appear subordinate. He spoke more like the head of a vassal state.
text: The impression it left on me, a strong supporter of the meeting, is that “something is not right here.” The president went out of his way to appear subordinate. He spoke more like the head of a vassal state.

html: I suspect that many of the people defending the press conference performance did not watch it in its entirety—or at all. If they had, they would know that it didn’t achieve the desired effect of bringing America and Russia closer; in fact, it did just the opposite.
text: I suspect that many of the people defending the press conference performance did not watch it in its entirety—or at all. If they had, they would know that it didn’t achieve the desired effect of bringing America and Russia closer; in fact, it did just the opposite.

html: Yet, that’s precisely the false conclusion some are making. I’ve heard it said that anyone who disapproves of what took place at the press conference is pro-war or anti-Trump. No, some of us are just concerned about the bizarre behavior of our president at a press conference.
text: Yet, that’s precisely the false conclusion some are making. I’ve heard it said that anyone who disapproves of what took place at the press conference is pro-war or anti-Trump. No, some of us are just concerned about the bizarre behavior of our president at a press conference.

html: We must not, however, fall for the logical fallacy that because diplomacy and dialogue are good, @POTUS’s performance at the press conference was good.

html: I believe that this aspect of libertarianism—the desire to seek friendship and peace whenever possible—is among its most appealing qualities.
text: I believe that this aspect of libertarianism—the desire to seek friendship and peace whenever possible—is among its most appealing qualities.

html: For my part, I have urged presidents to meet with the leaders of Russia, North Korea, Cuba, and other countries to build better relationships. These interactions make it possible to change behavior, to turn foes into friends.

html: We say diplomacy and dialogue are good. Few Americans would disagree with that. Peace and prosperity can’t be secured without communication and engagement.

html: This illustration is not meant to suggest that humans can design a perfect tax code. But when the government intentionally gives a special tax break to one entity, not only is the government undermining the Rule of Law, but it also is knowingly harming the economy.
text: This illustration is not meant to suggest that humans can design a perfect tax code. But when the government intentionally gives a special tax break to one entity, not only is the government undermining the Rule of Law, but it also is knowingly harming the economy.

html: We can imagine variations of this illustration. For example, maybe Al, Bo, Cy, and Di already live in the same state, and then the government gives Di a special tax break for "economic development." The end result, however, is the same: The special break is economically harmful.
text: We can imagine variations of this illustration. For example, maybe Al, Bo, Cy, and Di already live in the same state, and then the government gives Di a special tax break for "economic development." The end result, however, is the same: The special break is economically harmful.

html: When advocates of Di's special tax break talk about the economic growth and jobs it will create, they commit the broken window fallacy: https://fee.org/articles/the-broken-window/ …. They ignore the break's opportunity cost; the government has deprived Al, Bo, and Cy of a tax break. That's a net loss.

They ignore the break's opportunity cost; the government has deprived Al, Bo, and Cy of a tax break. That's a net loss.

html: For a primer on why the free market is superior to central planning, read this: https://fee.org/articles/the-use-of-knowledge-in-society/ …. In short, keeping more money in the hands of everyone produces better economic outcomes than giving a special advantage to one person.

html: We could rerun this illustration at a much lower level of government spending, and the relevant analysis again would be how best to tax at this level of spending: Is it best to give one person a very large tax break or to give everyone a modest tax break?
text: We could rerun this illustration at a much lower level of government spending, and the relevant analysis again would be how best to tax at this level of spending: Is it best to give one person a very large tax break or to give everyone a modest tax break?

html: If your reply is "give others a tax break, too," then you've missed the point. You can't give others a tax break AND hold all else equal. The budget must be balanced; government spending would have to be cut. The relevant analysis is how best to tax at a GIVEN level of spending.

html: Advocates of Di's special tax break are saying that, ALL ELSE EQUAL, they would rather give Di a very large tax break (75%) than give everyone a modest tax break. In other words, they believe that government central planners can outperform the market by shifting money to Di.

html: What about the claim that Di's arrival will boost the economy and more than pay for her special tax break? Many of the proponents of this view seem unaware that they are advocating central planning, a main tenet of socialism. To see this, let's return to the illustration.

html: The fact that Di is receiving services paid for by others rather than dollar bills from others does not make the transfer any less a welfare subsidy.
text: The fact that Di is receiving services paid for by others rather than dollar bills from others does not make the transfer any less a welfare subsidy.

html: Meanwhile, Di is living large. She is paying only $1 in annual taxes while receiving $3.25 to $4 in government services. The difference is a welfare subsidy to her, no less than if the government forced Al, Bo, and Cy to write her a check or hand her some cash.
text: Meanwhile, Di is living large. She is paying only $1 in annual taxes while receiving $3.25 to $4 in government services. The difference is a welfare subsidy to her, no less than if the government forced Al, Bo, and Cy to write her a check or hand her some cash.

html: Even if the government convinces Di to bear some of the additional tax burden, or finds another way to raise revenue, if any portion of the $3 comes from Al, Bo, and Cy, they will pay more in taxes than they receive in services, thanks to the government's special break for Di.
text: Even if the government convinces Di to bear some of the additional tax burden, or finds another way to raise revenue, if any portion of the $3 comes from Al, Bo, and Cy, they will pay more in taxes than they receive in services, thanks to the government's special break for Di.

html: Di's annual taxes are fixed at $1, so the additional $3 will have to come from Al, Bo, and Cy. Consequently, Al, Bo, and Cy will have to pay $5 per person in taxes, to receive $4 per person in services, thanks to the government's special break for Di.
text: Di's annual taxes are fixed at $1, so the additional $3 will have to come from Al, Bo, and Cy. Consequently, Al, Bo, and Cy will have to pay $5 per person in taxes, to receive $4 per person in services, thanks to the government's special break for Di.

html: Suppose the government attempts to maintain government services at the level provided prior to Di's arrival, i.e., $4 per person in services. Since the state now has four people, the government will need to collect $16 in taxes. It currently collects $13.
text: Suppose the government attempts to maintain government services at the level provided prior to Di's arrival, i.e., $4 per person in services. Since the state now has four people, the government will need to collect $16 in taxes. It currently collects $13.

html: In other words, Al, Bo, and Cy now get less for each tax dollar; their effective tax rate has gone up, thanks to the government's special break for Di.
text: In other words, Al, Bo, and Cy now get less for each tax dollar; their effective tax rate has gone up, thanks to the government's special break for Di.

html: Now the state has four people. The government collects $13 in taxes ($4 + $4 + $4 + $1) to be spent on services. But because government services are distributed equally, Al, Bo, and Cy now receive only $3.25 each in services ($13 / 4), even though each still pays $4 in taxes.
text: Now the state has four people. The government collects $13 in taxes ($4 + $4 + $4 + $1) to be spent on services. But because government services are distributed equally, Al, Bo, and Cy now receive only $3.25 each in services ($13 / 4), even though each still pays $4 in taxes.

html: Suppose the government wants to attract a new person, Di, to the state. The government is excited about all the business Di will bring, so it promises Di that her annual taxes will be only $1 if she makes the move. Di is thrilled and accepts the offer.

html: Imagine a state with only three people: Al, Bo, and Cy. Each person pays $4 in annual taxes, so the government collects $12 total. The government spends all that money providing services. It distributes services equally among its residents and is required to balance its budget.

html: Here’s my floor speech from 2011 regarding @POTUS44’s unconstitutional war in Libya: http://youtu.be/XsEDLxi45u4 . Please view & share. @POTUS risks making the same mistakes in Syria. The people must speak on war through the votes of their representatives. Our Constitution demands it.

html: The Constitution makes offensive military action without congressional approval unconstitutional. The War Powers Resolution is unnecessary but consistent in that regard. Don’t fall for the lie that the WPR grants authority for “limited” offensive action without approval. Thread:https://twitter.com/justinamash/status/983506478605701120 …

html: There are good reasons why a particular person might not have signed one of the letters: The House membership is different. In addition, a person might not have known about one of them, or might have been sick or away that day, or perhaps had a nuanced but valid objection to one.
